content.description: 7 bolts lead to rings at the anchor. A single ring gets you out of the gully back down to the bike path. Lots of loose rock.
content.location: Driving North on Hwy 61 from Two Harbors, Pass through Silver Creek Tunnel and park at the parking area on your right. Hike South to the set of information plaques. Scramble up the gully to the base of the route.

content.description: Anyone with route name or FA information share below. Start up the bolted slab clipping many bolts as you go. The crux is figuring out how to get into the finger crack above. The number of bolts on this climb would make it a good route for the budding 5.10 leader.
content.protection: Bolts, 10 of them plus a bolted rap anchor. The finger crack takes good pro for those with a set of 0.5-1 cams.
content.location: From the parking area on the east side of the tunnel, walk along the path for few minutes. Continue more than halfway along the cliff until you reach a distinctly vertical wall with three bolted lines near each other. This is the climber's leftmost line of bolts.

content.description: A low-angle partially bolted route on the climber's left side of the information wall (the wall in front of the information boards). Start next to a black bolt about 3 feet off the ground. Climb more or less straight up for the entirety of the route. Pitch 1 (80ft) has 3 bolts, the first useful one is about 40ft up. The P1 chains have a couple of links, then rings. I believe most people only climb P1. Pitch 2 (30ft) can be belayed from a ledge protected by bolts, left of the P1 chains. 2-3 bolts protect the climbing before the top set of chains.Listed as route 3 in the Silver Creek Cliffs guide (see here).
content.protection: P1: 3 bolts, a few cams for support in the range of .3-#2 BD.    P2: 2-3 bolts, maybe a cam or two to really stich it up.    I don't recommend a rope shorter than 60m.
content.location: Walk up the path, on the left side of the first wall in front of the information signs, this route starts at a black bolt a few feet off the ground.

content.description: Route #6 in the PDFFat fists/hands crack (could feel more offwidthy for smaller handed folks). Crack is less than vertical in a dihedral, plenty of good stemming. Work your way up to the small roof on pro, clip the bolt just before the roof, find the good jams under the roof, reach up and around. Once over the roof, traverse left to the anchors. Very well protected route, and super fun!Best to have someone second this climb to clean gear and then rap from the anchor
content.protection: Cams #2-#4 (1 #2, 2 #3s, 1 #4 if looking to really stitch it up) and 3 quickdraws
content.location: Just north of Elyse's Revenge, about 30-50 feet maybe?

content.description: A short sport route climbing a slopey and scrappy arete.  The rock quality is poor but large pieces are not likely to come off...work your way up and pay attention to your feet.   One of the top anchors is a spinner...
content.location: About a third of the way down the cliff heading south...look for the arete and the bolts.

content.description:
Short but Sweet. Bouldery off the ground to a jug. If your shorter it could possibly be the hardest single move on the route. Traverse the horizontal crack to your first piece (#4) about 10ft up. If your not comfortable climbing to that point a few pads would help. The Crux is about 3/4 of the way up and a little spicy getting to your last piece.

 You can climb the route (name Unknown) To the left to get up top and build a gear anchor. You’ve got to get a bit creative. Look for the old bolt stubs up top. These can be slung with a stopper and incorporate into your anchor. 

 Worth the time? For how short it is, it has great movement and is a little exciting up high. If this route seems too short for ya then pile up the pads! Boom just like that.. 30ft doesn’t seem so short anymore! This would make for a great highball Boulder! Have fun!
content.protection: Cams. BD #4, #3, .5 or .4 in that order. There is nothing else
content.location: The route is located at the sounthern end of the cliff band. Look for the right leaning crack. The start is about 10-15ft right of a 4 bolt sport route.

content.description: Anyone with route name and FA information, share below. Start at the bottom of the obvious bolted flake. Pull a funky move to get off the ground and follow the weakness to a bolted anchor.
content.protection: This route obviously goes on gear, so if you brought a rack go ahead and bring a single of 0.5-2 sized cams and just be careful of the loose stuff in the crack and the parts of the flake that are hollow sounding. If that is not your cup of tea, clip the bolts, there are 5 or 6 of them, bolted rap anchor.
content.location: From the parking area on the east side of the tunnel, walk along the path for few minutes. Continue more than halfway along the cliff until you reach a distinctly vertical wall with three bolted lines near each other.This route is the middle line of bolts.

content.description: Route #5 in the PDF. Bob's hands must be smaller than mine, start was more fingers but it did get a bit wider in some spots. Scramble up the loose crumbly rock up to a pair of bolts to belay off of (could treat the scramble as pitch 1 and rope up, but not necessary). From the bolts, pull a somewhat tricky start to gain access into the crack. Run up the crack until you spot some bolts, keep going, and eventually reach the chains atop the rounded and gravely top. Descent: From top anchor, rap down to belay station at base of crack. Either downclimb the crumbly scramble or rap again from anchor. Personally I would choose to rap againUnsure on a rating of 5.7, may be easier or harder. I've felt the first third of the crack is the most awkward/tricky. PDF does not give a suggested grade
content.protection: Nuts, hexes, smaller cams (~0.4 - 1 maybe, I only used a 0.5 Friend), at least 2 quick draws for bolts up high
content.location: Route is directly south(?) of Uncharted Waters and Information Wall

content.description: Anyone with route name or FA information share below!Start near two low bolts (like 2.5 feet off the ground to be used for lead soloing?) left of a finger crack, pull into the crack and clip a bolt, follow the crack/flake up a small corner past 3 more bolts to a bolted anchor. There is an option to continue past the anchor and a couple more bolts to the anchor over the route to the right of this climb.
content.location: From the parking area on the east side of the tunnel, walk along the path for few minutes. Continue more than halfway down the cliff until you reach a distinctly vertical wall with three bolted lines near each other.This route is the climber's rightmost line of bolts.

content.description: Anyone with route name or first ascent information, please share below!Start on the right of the black and white streaked rock near a new bolt and a rusty old bolt with an upturned Leeper hanger. Climb the right-hand crack past some crumbly holds to a higher bolt on the arete. Follow the crack around the arete and up a headwall past another bolt. A couple more steps and bolts bring you to the top. A fun route with surprisingly good movement.
content.protection: Small cams from .3-.75 plus a couple draws for the bolts, there are 4 of them.
content.location: From the parking lot on the east side of the tunnel, walk along the path for a few minutes until you reach the western quarter of the cliff. Look for an obvious black and white striped section of the wall with two cracks rising out if it.This route is the climber's right-hand crack.

content.description: Anyone with route name or FA information please share!Start on a pedestal left of the black and white streaked wall. Climb and faint corner clipping a couple bolts as you go. Encounter the crux and pull onto a ledge. Continue up the slab split by an aesthetic finger crack that takes great pro. Reach another ledge with a bolt and climb easy terrain up to a brief wide section (depending on your OW skills, this may be is the crux?) before the anchor.This could be a good first trad lead.
content.protection: Mixed gear. 3-4 bolts plus cams to #2 and a bolted rap anchor. Optional #5 Camalot for the wide section up top. There are some fixed metal pipes fit into the wide crack like homemade big bros to protect the wide section. A cleaver way to not carry big cams, but they are far back in the crack and could be tough to use. Sling them at your own risk.
content.location: From the parking lot on the east side of the tunnel, walk along the path for a few minutes until you reach the western quarter of the cliff. Look for an obvious black and white striped section of the wall with two cracks rising out if it.This route is climber's left of the black and white streaked wall near a large corner. There is a low bolt with an upturned hanger below two more bolts at the start of this route.

content.description: Anyone with route name or FA info, please share below. At the black and white streaked wall, start below the left-hand crack next to a bolt with upturned Leeper hanger. Shimmy up the wide section of the crack until you can get a deep hand jam. Work around a chockstone on good feet and try to keep the munge and dirt raining from of the crack out of your eyes. Pull the mini roof (using a clutch undercling) and jam up the crack above. Flop onto a small ledge without pully too hard on the flake above. Follow easy terrain either left or right the anchor of your choice.
content.location: From the parking lot on the east side of the tunnel, walk along the path for a few minutes until you reach the western quarter of the cliff. Look for an obvious black and white striped section of the wall with two cracks rising out if it.This route is the climber's left-hand crack.

content.description: There are few bolted sport routes and potential for a few trad lines here but the rock is pretty crumbly and more cleaning would be in order. There is a bike route directly below the cliff and since MNDOT maintains the area, bikers and tourists get the right of way.
